comment_0: I wouldn't say it's a sad song. More of a proud song. His not sad that his getting old, but proud of himself and the way he accomplished his challenges throughout his life. He sums it up perfectly in the last verse. "For what is a man, what has he got? If not himself, then he has naught." It's a lovely song, and a modest one as well. Doesn't it make you feel that when your older you want to look back on your life and say, "I did it my way" and then smile? If the answer is yes then I guess Old Blue Eyes has made you feel exactly what he wanted you to feel.

comment_3: Pretty simple. Already been stated, but I'll say it 'my way' (heh heh heh). Looking back at your life when you're older, and being proud and feeling accomplished that you went through your life, took the beatings, and did everything your way. Like said before, very modest song.VERY fitting for Sinatra. He seemed like a really tough, not gonna take crap from anyone guy to me, and this song just proves my point. He was who he was, and he did things his way, and he made it through everything.

comment_23:
Paul Anka wrote the lyrics for this song in '69 and gave them to Frank Sinatra when Frank had it with the music business. He wanted to quit, Paul thought Frank had so much more to bring the world (he was right), wrote the song in a night and when he gave the song to Frank, Frank was immediatelly convinced he should stay a few more years and did.
I heard this song a million times and will hear it a million times more, not because i put it on but because it's everywhere, it's musical history .... and you know what, i'll never get tired of it.

comment_27:
So I was listening to this song today, and I realized something. The lyrics play out as an almost beautiful suicide note. I don't know why, but I started picturing everyting in my head. I man who has been taking crap his entire life finally loses it and decides to end his life. The line "I took the blows" is right as he fires a gun at his head. And the last line of his note is also the last line of the song: "Yes, it was my way."

I know that's not the true meaning, but it works really well.  It's kind of eerie when I listen to it now with that in mind.

Maybe I'm the only one who's thought that.

comment_35:
There's no one else i want to hear sing this song. Sinatra had (has as some say, his spirit never died) quite a remarkable life. Hearing such a man belt it out makes my heart ache, and tears begin to surface.

As far as music ventures, from the beginning of classical music to the normaility of hearing Death Metal, this can be as close to a perfect song as one can get. I'm not saying it's the best i've ever heard, but what i am saying is this song is extraordinary.

This song represents a retrospective point of view, when death is ready to take you. One looks back at the memories. The good, the bad. The gorgeous, and ugly. An overal look at the recolections of his or her life, is an assesment of yourself as to whether or not you lived your life to the fullest. In Sinatra's case, you better fucking believe his life was worth it. i love this song. as do i love Sinatra.

comment_39: Doing it "My Way" is not always the best way to do it, too little too late:(
comment_40: Possibly one of the most frequently misinterpreted songs of all time.  Motivational speakers etc, often use this song as an example to get their point across.  They seem to think it is a song about self-reliance and self-sufficiency; a sort of 'I can do it all on my own - I don't need any help'.  Either that, or they seem to think it's about refusing to humble yourself and accept guidance from a higher authority.  Well, there may be a small element of that in it, but I don't think that's what it's mainly about.  Paul Anka, a friend of Frank's, wrote the song, around 1969, and he wrote it with Frank in mind, for Frank to sing, as sort of an autobiographical piece.  So what's it REALLY about???  I think it's a defiant refusal on Frank's part to justify himself to the world, and in particular the press.  Many famous people appear to think they owe an explanation of themselves to the world, and in particular the news and media, and then, having courted the attention of the press, they end up regretting it.  Princess Diana was a classic example.  Frank never did this, despite massive questions remaining unanswered about his mafia associations.  In the late 1930s, Frank had begun working as a full time professional singer, but he couldn't get a decent break, and felt that certain people were opposing him.  So he went to his cousin, 'Lucky' Luciano, who ran the New York mob, and they did him a favour.  After that, coincidentally, Frank's career took off.  Frank's sordid mob connections remained in place for many years after that.  And that is why, if ever there was someone who owed it to the world to explain themselves, it was Frank.  But he never did.  So when Paul Anka/Frank Sinatra are saying, "I did it my way", what they're really saying, is that Frank broke from the norm as a notorious celebrity by resisting the pressure to justify himself and his associations.  If only the many famous people today who are pouring their hearts out in the gutter press could take a leaf out of his book.....
comment_41:
The song is about not living a life that others tell you to live (traditional institutions like church, school, family), but to chose to have a choice in life. The high pitch of "I did it my way" expresses the culminating point of glory. Life on Earth includes both sorrow and joy, and the best we could choose is to craft our journey and to lean on the bright side and see the positive things. Of course the song touches on elements of spirituality and a lot more. I'll start upvoting good comments now, because some of you mentioned excellent ideas, indeed "this is the ultimate song"

I should not forget to tell you about the movie / tale "Tristan and Iseult" which includes the same topic. Even though everyone is against the affair between the two young people, they did it their way. And to quote Tristan, "love is greater than life and death", or passion to do what you want. 
All the best to you citizens of the world!!!

comment_43: The song was originally written by french artist Michel Sardou, it's original french name was "Comme d'habitude". The music stayed the same, but Paul Anka wrote new lyrics and made the song for Sinatra. The original french song and the english version have nothing in common as for their meanings. This is the most covered song ever. I like it, and boy, what a perfect fit for Frank Sinatra. :)
comment_44: Damn, I came here to post the French thing, looks like you beat me by a couple hours. Glad to see at least someone knows their shit.
comment_45: I think this song is about men having sex in public toilets. its all all the clues there but it seems that they've not been picked up on. it would have a certain irony if one of the biggest homophobes in the industry was singing about going to tea rooms (cottaging) for sex. I guess not many will agree with me, but read the words without the rose coloured glasses folks. I think it has been the bigest practical joke getting Frank to sing a queer song.
